statements.name: PROC CASUTIL
statements.description: Manages tables and files in SAS Cloud Analytic Services.
statements.help:
PROC CASUTIL   <options>;
	APPEND  SOURCE="table-1"<SRCCASLIB="caslib" > <DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options)>
		TARGET="table-2" <TGTCASLIB="caslib">;
	ALTERTABLE  CASDATA="table-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> <LABEL="label">
		<RENAME | CASOUT="table-name">
		<COLUMNS={column-options-1 <,{column-options-n}>}>
		<COLUMNORDER={"variable-name" <,"variable-name-n">}>
		<DROP={"variable-name" <,"variable-name-n">}>
		<KEEP={"variable-name" <,"variable-name-n">}>;
	CONTENTS  CASDATA="table-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> <options>;
	 DELETESOURCE  CASDATA="file-name"  <INCASLIB="caslib"> <DATASOURCEOPTIONS={data-source-options}> <DELETEOPTIONS={delete-options}> <QUIET>;
	COPY   CASDATA="file-name" <INCASLIB="caslib">
		CASOUT="table-name"<OUTCASLIB="caslib">
		
		 <DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options)>
			<INDEXVARS=((variable-name-1),<(variable-name-n)>)><options>;
	DROPTABLE  CASDATA="table-name"  <INCASLIB="caslib"> <QUIET>;
	INDEX  CASDATA="table-name" 
		<INCASLIB="caslib">
		<VARS={ {casinvardesc-1}, {<casinvardesc-n>} }>
		<WHERE="where-expression <logical-operatorwhere-expression">>
		<IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE=file-type <file-type-options>)>
		<DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options)>
		<CASOUT="table-name">
		<OUTCASLIB="caslib">
		<LABEL="label-name">
		<COMPRESS ><PROMOTE ><REPLACE ><REPLICATION|COPIES= integer>
		<INDEXVARS=((variable-name-1),<(variable-name-n)>)>;
	LIST  <FILES | TABLES>  <options>;
	LOAD  CASDATA="file-name" | DATA=SAS-data-set | FILE="SAS-file" <options>;
	PARTITION  CASDATA="table-name" 
		<INCASLIB="caslib">
		<VARS={ {casinvardesc-1}, {<casinvardesc-n>} }>
		<WHERE="where-expression <logical-operatorwhere-expression">>
		<PARTITIONBY | GROUPBY=(group-by-variable-1 <group-by-variable-n>)>
		<IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE=file-type <file-type-options>)>
		<DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options)>
		<CASOUT="table-name">
		<OUTCASLIB="caslib">
		<LABEL="label-name">
		<COMPRESS ><PROMOTE ><REPLACE ><REPLICATION|COPIES= integer>
		<INDEXVARS=((variable-name-1),<(variable-name-n)>)>
	PROMOTE   CASDATA="table-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> 
		<CASOUT="table-name"> 
		<OUTCASLIB="caslib">
		  <DROP | KEEP>; 
	SAVE   CASDATA="table-name "  <INCASLIB="caslib">
		<CASOUT="file-name"> <OUTCASLIB="caslib"> <EXPORTOPTIONS={export-options}> <IMPORTDATASOURCEOPTIONS = {import-data-source-options}>
		  <options>;
	UPDATE 
               CASDATA="table-name" 
		<INCASLIB="caslib">
               
		<SET={ {var="variable-name", value="string"} }>
               
		<WHERE="where-expression <logical-operatorwhere-expression">;>
            QUIT;

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the input caslib for the procedure. This option does not change the active caslib for your session. If you do not specify this option here or in a statement, such as LOAD, then the active caslib is used.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the output caslib for the procedure. This option does not change the active caslib for your session. If you do not specify this option here or in a statement, such as LOAD, then the active caslib is used.

arguments.name: SESSREF=
arguments.description: specifies the session to use with the procedure. If you omit SESSREF=, then procedure uses the session that specified in the &_SESSREF_ macro variable.

statements.name: APPEND
statements.description: The append statement concatenates two tables.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: specifies the source table that is appended to the target table.

arguments.name: TARGET
arguments.description: specifies the target table.

arguments.name: SRCCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that contains the source table.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: TGTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that contains the target table.

statements.name: ALTERTABLE
statements.description: The ALTERTABLE statement enables you to change your table. For example, you can rename the table, change labels and formats, drop columns, and so on.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the in-memory table to change.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to change. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a new label for the table.

arguments.name: RENAME
arguments.description: specifies a new name for the table.

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: specifies how to alter columns. After you specify the column name, you can drop a column or assign a new format, label, or name. Following are the column options:

arguments.name: COLUMNORDER=
arguments.description: specifies the order of the columns.

arguments.name: DROP=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to drop from the table.

arguments.name: KEEP=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to keep in the table.

statements.name: CONTENTS
statements.description: The CONTENTS statement displays table metadata such as column names and data types for files or in-memory tables.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the file or table.

arguments.name: IMPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the file format and options. Specify this option only if you specify a file name in the CASDATA= option. If you want to display metadata for an in-memory table (the result of a LOAD statement), then do not specify this option.

arguments.name: FILETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the file format.

arguments.name: file-type-options
arguments.description: specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that is associated with the file or table. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: VARS=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to include. If you do not include this option, all variables are included.

statements.name: COPY
statements.description: The COPY statement copies one table from a caslib's data source to another. The copy of the table is saved to the data source that is associated with the caslib.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the file to load from the server-side data source that is associated with the INCASLIB= option or the active caslib.

arguments.name: CASOUT=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative name for the file. A file is created in the data source that is associated with the caslib from the OUTCASLIB= option. By default, a .sashdat file suffix is added when you save to a path-based caslib. If you specify a .csv suffix, a CSV file is saved.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to copy. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: INDEXVARS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of variables to create indexes for in the output data.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative caslib to use for the copied table. If specified, this option overrides the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: specifies to compress the data in the copied file.

arguments.name: COPIES=
arguments.description: specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. This value is ignored unless you save to the SASHDAT file format.

arguments.name: GROUPBY=
arguments.description: specifies the names of the variables to use for partitioning the SASHDAT file.

arguments.name: IMPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the input file format and options. Specify this option only if you want to read a file from the input caslib's data source and copy it without loading it to memory.

arguments.name: FILETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the file format.

arguments.name: file-type-options
arguments.description: specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: ORDERBY=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to use for ordering observations within partitions. This parameter applies to partitioned tables.

arguments.name: PROMOTE
arguments.description: specifies to load the table with global scope. This makes the table available to all sessions that use the caslib, subject to access controls. The caslib must also have global scope.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that a new file with a given name replaces an existing file with the same name.

arguments.name: VARS=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to load into the table. If you do not specify this option, then all variables are loaded into the table.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies the format to apply to the variable.

arguments.name: FORMATTEDLENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the format field length plus the format precision length.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies the descriptive label for the variable.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name for the variable.

arguments.name: NFD=
arguments.description: specifies the format precision length.

arguments.name: NFL=
arguments.description: specifies the format field length.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: The specification for this option is described in WHERE= for the LOAD statement.

statements.name: DELETESOURCE
statements.description: The DELETESOURCE statement removes a file from the data source that is associated with a caslib. You do not need to drop an in-memory table with the same name before using this statement.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the file to remove.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that is associated with the file to remove. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies data source options.

arguments.name: DELETEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the settings for deleting a file from a data source.

arguments.name: QUIET=
arguments.description: suppresses error messages and avoids setting the SYSERR automatic macro variable when the specified table or file is not found.

statements.name: DROPTABLE
statements.description: The DROPTABLE statement removes a table from memory on SAS Cloud Analytic Services.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the table to remove from memory.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that is associated with the table to remove. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: QUIET
arguments.description: suppresses error messages and avoids setting the SYSERR automatic macro variable when the specified table is not found.

statements.name: INDEX
statements.description: The INDEX statement enables you to create indexes on one or more table variables.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the in-memory table to change.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to change. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: VARS=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to use in the action. The casinvardesc-n value can be one or more of the following:

arguments.name: format=
arguments.description: specifies the format to apply to the variable.

arguments.name: formattedLength=
arguments.description: specifies the length of format field plus the format precision.

arguments.name: label=
arguments.description: specifies the descriptive label for the variable.

arguments.name: name=
arguments.description: specifies the name for the variable.

arguments.name: nfd=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the format precision.

arguments.name: nfl=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the format field.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: specifies an expression for subsetting the input data.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators, operands, and SAS functions. An operand is a variable, a SAS function, or a constant. An operator is a symbol that requests a comparison, logical operation, or arithmetic calculation. The expression must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.

arguments.name: IMPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the file format and options. If you do not specify the FILETYPE= option, the server attempts to determine the file type based on the file name suffix, such as .sashdat, .csv, and so on. Files with a .txt suffix are imported as a CSV file.

arguments.name: FILETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the file format.

arguments.name: file-type-options
arguments.description: specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: CASOUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name to use for the in-memory table.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative caslib to use for the in-memory table. If specified, this option overrides the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the table. The label can be up to 256 characters. If the label text contains single quotation marks, enclose the label in double quotation marks. To remove a label from a table, assign a blank space that is enclosed in quotation marks.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: specifies to compress the output table. This option is supported with the DATA= argument only.

arguments.name: PROMOTE
arguments.description: specifies to load the table with global scope. This makes the table available to all sessions that use the caslib, subject to access controls. The caslib must also have global scope.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that an in-memory table with a given name replaces an existing in-memory table with the same name.

arguments.name: REPLICATION
arguments.description: specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. Larger values use more memory and can result in slower performance, but provide high availability for data in the event of a node failure.

arguments.name: INDEXVARS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of variables to create indexes for in the output data.

statements.name: LIST
statements.description: The LIST statement lists files from a caslib’s data source or in-memory tables in a caslib.

arguments.name: FILES
arguments.description: specifies whether to list the files from a caslib's data source or in-memory tables.

arguments.name: TABLES
arguments.description: specifies whether to list the files from a caslib's data source or in-memory tables.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that is associated with the tables or files to list. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: NOSUBDIRS
arguments.description: specifies to exclude subdirectories from the results.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: SUBDIR=
arguments.description: specifies to list the files in the specified subdirectory.

statements.name: LOAD
statements.description: The LOAD statement reads data from a file in a caslib’s data source, a libref, or a client-side file and loads it into memory on SAS Cloud Analytic Services.
statements.help:
Form 1: 
LOAD  CASDATA="file-name" <INCASLIB="caslib"> CASOUT="table-name"
	<OUTCASLIB="caslib"> 
		<IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE="file-type" <file-type-options>)>
		<GROUPBY=(group-by-variable-1 <group-by-variable-2 ...>)> <ORDERBY=(variable-1
		 <variable-2 ...>)>
		<LABEL="table-description">
		<DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options)>
		<PROMOTE | REPLACE>
		 <COPIES=integer>
		<VARS=((casinvardesc-1) <, (casinvardesc-2),  ...>)>
		<WHERE="where-expression-1 <logical-operatorwhere-expression-2>">
		;
Form 2: 
LOAD  DATA=SAS-data-set<(data-set-options)> 
	
	<CASOUT="table-name"> 
		<OUTCASLIB="caslib"> 
		<APPEND | COMPRESS>
		<GROUPBY=(group-by-variable-1 <group-by-variable-2 ...>) > <ORDERBY=(variable-1
		 <variable-2 ...>)>
		<LABEL="table-description">
		<DATASOURCEOPTIONS=(data-source-options)>
		<PROMOTE | REPLACE>
		<REPEAT>
		 <COPIES=integer>
		<NCHARMULTIPLIER=n>
		<TRANSCODE_FAIL=ERROR | WARN | SILENT >
		<TIMEOUTSECONDS=n>
		<WRITETRANSFERSIZE=integer | integerK | integerM | integerG>;
Form 3: 
LOAD  FILE="path-to-client-file" CASOUT="table-name"
	
	 <OUTCASLIB="caslib"> 
		<COMPRESS>
		<IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE=file-type <file-type-options>)>
		<LABEL="table-description">
		<PROMOTE | REPLACE>
		  <COPIES=integer>
		<TIMEOUTSECONDS=n>
		<WRITETRANSFERSIZE=integer | integerK | integerM | integerG>;
Form 4: 
LOAD  FILE=fileref  CASOUT="table-name"
	
	 <OUTCASLIB="caslib"> 
		<COMPRESS>
		<IMPORTOPTIONS=(FILETYPE=file-type <file-type-options>)>
		<LABEL="table-description">
		<PROMOTE | REPLACE>
		  <COPIES=integer>
		<TIMEOUTSECONDS=n>
		<WRITETRANSFERSIZE=integer | integerK | integerM | integerG>;

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the file to load from the server-side data source that is associated with the INCASLIB= option or the active caslib.

arguments.name: CASOUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name to use for the in-memory table.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the libref and data set name to use.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies an external file that is accessible to the SAS client host. Use this option to upload a file to the server and import the data. Do not use this option to import a SAS data set, use the DATA= option.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: specifies an external file that is accessible with a file reference. Use this option to upload a file to the server and import the data. Do not use this option to import a SAS data set, use the DATA= option.

arguments.name: APPEND
arguments.description: adds the rows from the SAS data set in the DATA= argument to the end of an in-memory table. This option is supported with the DATA= argument only.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: specifies to compress the output table. This option is supported with the DATA= argument only.

arguments.name: COPIES=
arguments.description: specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. Larger values use more memory and can result in slower performance, but provide high availability for data in the event of a node failure.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: GROUPBY=
arguments.description: specifies the names of the variables to use for grouping results.

arguments.name: IMPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the file format and options. If you do not specify the FILETYPE= option, the server attempts to determine the file type based on the file name suffix, such as .sashdat, .csv, and so on. Files with a .txt suffix are imported as a CSV file.

arguments.name: FILETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the file format.

arguments.name: file-type-options
arguments.description: specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib that is associated with the file to load. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the table. The label can be up to 256 characters. If the label text contains single quotation marks, enclose the label in double quotation marks. To remove a label from a table, assign a blank space that is enclosed in quotation marks.

arguments.name: NCHARMULTIPLIER=
arguments.description: specifies the multiplication factor used when transcoding.

arguments.name: ORDERBY=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to use for ordering observations within partitions. This parameter applies to partitioned tables.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative caslib to use for the in-memory table. If specified, this option overrides the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: PROMOTE
arguments.description: specifies to load the table with global scope. This makes the table available to all sessions that use the caslib, subject to access controls. The caslib must also have global scope.

arguments.name: REPEAT
arguments.description: specifies to duplicate the rows for the table on every machine of a distributed server. Making duplicate copies of tables can be useful in cases like a dimension table that is used in a join. This option is supported with the DATA= argument only and cannot be combined with the GROUPBY= option.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that an in-memory table with a given name replaces an existing in-memory table with the same name.

arguments.name: TIMEOUTSECONDS=
arguments.description: specifies the client inactivity time-out interval in seconds. If SAS stops transferring data to the server, the server starts the inactivity timer for the specified duration and cancels the request if SAS does not resume data transfer.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE_FAIL=
arguments.description: specifies how the engine handles transcoding errors.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: writes an error message to the SAS log. Processing stops.

arguments.name: WARN
arguments.description: writes a warning message to the SAS log. Processing continues.

arguments.name: SILENT
arguments.description: transcoding errors are ignored. Processing continues.

arguments.name: VARS=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to load into the table. If you do not specify this option, then all variables are loaded into the table.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies the format to apply to the variable.

arguments.name: FORMATTEDLENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the format field length plus the format precision length.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies the descriptive label for the variable.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: specifies the name for the variable.

arguments.name: NFD=
arguments.description: specifies the format precision length.

arguments.name: NFL=
arguments.description: specifies the format field length.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: specifies conditions for selecting observations from the data.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators, operands, and SAS functions. An operand is a variable, a SAS function, or a constant. An operator is a symbol that requests a comparison, logical operation, or arithmetic calculation. The expression must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.

arguments.name: WRITETRANSFERSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of bytes the procedure writes when transferring data to the CAS server.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: specifies the total number of bytes to read.

arguments.name: integerK
arguments.description: specifies the total number of kilobytes to read.

arguments.name: integerM
arguments.description: specifies the total number of megabytes to read.

arguments.name: integerG
arguments.description: specifies the total number of gigabytes to read.

statements.name: PARTITION
statements.description: The PARTITION statement enables you to partition a table.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the in-memory table to change.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to change. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: VARS=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to use in the action. The casinvardesc-n value can be one or more of the following:

arguments.name: format=
arguments.description: specifies the format to apply to the variable.

arguments.name: formattedLength=
arguments.description: specifies the length of format field plus the format precision.

arguments.name: label=
arguments.description: specifies the descriptive label for the variable.

arguments.name: name=
arguments.description: specifies the name for the variable.

arguments.name: nfd=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the format precision.

arguments.name: nfl=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the format field.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: specifies an expression for subsetting the input data.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators, operands, and SAS functions. An operand is a variable, a SAS function, or a constant. An operator is a symbol that requests a comparison, logical operation, or arithmetic calculation. The expression must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.

arguments.name: PARTITIONBYGROUPBY=
arguments.description: specifies the names of the variables to use for grouping results.

arguments.name: IMPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the file format and options. If you do not specify the FILETYPE= option, the server attempts to determine the file type based on the file name suffix, such as .sashdat, .csv, and so on. Files with a .txt suffix are imported as a CSV file.

arguments.name: FILETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the file format.

arguments.name: file-type-options
arguments.description: specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: CASOUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name to use for the in-memory table.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative caslib to use for the in-memory table. If specified, this option overrides the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: specifies a descriptive label for the table. The label can be up to 256 characters. If the label text contains single quotation marks, enclose the label in double quotation marks. To remove a label from a table, assign a blank space that is enclosed in quotation marks.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: specifies to compress the output table. This option is supported with the DATA= argument only.

arguments.name: PROMOTE
arguments.description: specifies to load the table with global scope. This makes the table available to all sessions that use the caslib, subject to access controls. The caslib must also have global scope.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that an in-memory table with a given name replaces an existing in-memory table with the same name.

arguments.name: REPLICATION
arguments.description: specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. Larger values use more memory and can result in slower performance, but provide high availability for data in the event of a node failure.

arguments.name: INDEXVARS=
arguments.description: specifies the list of variables to create indexes for in the output data

statements.name: PROMOTE
statements.description: The PROMOTE statement copies a session-scope table to global scope.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the in-memory table to promote.

arguments.name: CASOUT=
arguments.description: specifies the name to use for the promoted table.

arguments.name: DROP
arguments.description: specifies to drop the session-scope table after promoting it to global scope, which is the default behavior and a best practice.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to promote. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: KEEP
arguments.description: specifies to keep the session-scope table after promoting it to global scope. This workflow is uncommon. The table precedence rules are that the session-local table is accessed before a global-scope table is accessed.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative caslib to use for the promoted table. If specified, this option overrides the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: QUIET
arguments.description: does not return a message with status and severity. If the QUIET option is not specified, then a message returns with status and severity.

statements.name: SAVE
statements.description: The SAVE statement creates a permanent copy of an in-memory table. The in-memory table is saved to the data source that is associated with the caslib.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the in-memory table to save.

arguments.name: CASOUT=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative name for the file. A file is created in the data source that is associated with the caslib from the OUTCASLIB= option. By default, a .sashdat file suffix is added when you save to a path-based caslib. If you specify a .csv suffix, a CSV file is saved.

arguments.name: EXPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the settings for saving a table to a data source.

arguments.name: IMPORTDATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: enables you to save an in-memory table to the specified data source.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to save. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: OUTCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies an alternative caslib to use for the saved table. If specified, this option overrides the OUTCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: specifies to compress the data in the saved file.

arguments.name: COPIES=
arguments.description: specifies the number of replicate copies of the rows to make for fault tolerance. This value is ignored unless you save to the SASHDAT file format.

arguments.name: DATASOURCEOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies overrides for the DATASOURCE= options for the input caslib. For more information, see and .For more information, see and .

arguments.name: GROUPBY=
arguments.description: specifies the names of the variables to use for partitioning the SASHDAT file.

arguments.name: IMPORTOPTIONS=
arguments.description: specifies the input file format and options. Specify this option only if you want to read a file from the input caslib's data source and save it without loading it to memory.

arguments.name: FILETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies the file format.

arguments.name: file-type-options
arguments.description: specifies options for importing the data. For more information, see and .

arguments.name: ORDERBY=
arguments.description: specifies the variables to use for ordering observations within partitions. This parameter applies to partitioned tables.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: specifies that a new file with a given name replaces an existing file with the same name.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: The specification for this option is described in WHERE= for the LOAD statement.

statements.name: UPDATE
statements.description: The UPDATE statement enables you to update rows in a table.

arguments.name: CASDATA=
arguments.description: specifies the name of the in-memory table to change.

arguments.name: INCASLIB=
arguments.description: specifies the caslib with the in-memory table to change. If specified, this option overrides the INCASLIB= value in the procedure statement or the active caslib.

arguments.name: SET=
arguments.description: specifies the variable name and the value to set. Use the where parameter to limit the updates to specific rows.

arguments.name: var=
arguments.description: specifies the column name to update.

arguments.name: value=
arguments.description: specifies the value to set the column to. Enclose the value in quotation marks even if the data type is numeric.

arguments.name: WHERE=
arguments.description: specifies an expression for subsetting the input data.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that consists of a sequence of operators, operands, and SAS functions. An operand is a variable, a SAS function, or a constant. An operator is a symbol that requests a comparison, logical operation, or arithmetic calculation. The expression must be enclosed in single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
